Alexander M. Carlisle...of the big shipbuilding firm of Harland & Wolff, at Belfast...talked about the new thousand-foot ocean giants that are soon to leave the yards at Belfast... He declared that the Olympic and Titanic would burst upon the world when they come here in 1911. 'Work on these big steamships is going on night and day,' he said, 'and we will have the Olympic ready for launching in October. Nothing can compare with them in size and beauty. You will get a revelation in room and decoration when these vessels come to New York.'" "The Olympic and the Titanic will have a speed of 21 knots... The staterooms will be unusually large, and there will be an abundance of room everywhere. For example, we will have an exceedingly large room off the dining saloon where people may meet before dinner and hold receptions. The decorations will be unsurpassed. They will be the most magnificent, but also the most substantial and solid that ever were put into a steamship." "We will launch the Olympic in October, and she should be in service in the middle of 1911. The Titanic will probably be ready about three or four months after the Olympic sails on her maiden passage.

MONSTER LINER LAUNCHED. Steamer Titanic Slides Into Water at Belfast. BELFAST, May 31.— Enthusiastic crowds lined the banks of the River Lagan and cheered lustily as the White Star Line's great steamer Titanic was launched with appropriate ceremonies this morning. The Titanic will enter the White Star's New York-Southampton service late in the year, but her sister vessel Olympic steams from Southampton two weeks hence for New York, and these two sea monsters, each 45,000 tons register, 882½ feet long and 92½ feet broad, boast the distinction of being the largest and finest vessels in the world. These massive ships are also notable for the enchanting beauty and the unusual spaciousness of their passenger accommodations, and in first, second, and third class the greatest comfort is promised. On both steamers, swimming pools, tennis and handball courts, and Turkish and electric bath establishments are among the innovations introduced for the pleasure of the passengers." a great swimming bath aboard both the Olympic and the Titanic, large enough to permit of diving.

"TITANIC'S MAIDEN TRIP." "Sister Ship to the Olympic of White Star Line Sails Next Week." "London, April 3— The gigantic new steamship Titanic of the White Star line arrived today at Southampton from the yards of her builders at Belfast. She is to be made ready for her maiden trip across the Atlantic, the start of which is scheduled for Wednesday of next week. The Titanic is a sister ship to the Olympic. She is 882½ feet long and has a displacement of 45,000 tons. The traveling list on the big ship will have 600 names on its first-class roll, in addition to 500 second-class and third-cabin passengers. To this will be added the crew of 890, making a total floating population of nearly 2,000."

ITANTIC SAILS ON HER FIRST VOYAGE." White Star Liner the Largest Vessel that Ever Sailed the Seas. "London, April 10.— Carrying 1400 passengers, the liner Titanic of the White Star Line, than which there is no larger vessel afloat, sailed from Southampton today on her maiden voyage bound for New York. The Titanic which is of 45,000 tons displacement is a sister ship to the Olympic." "All the special suites of rooms instituted as an innovation in the Titanic were occupied when the passage began. These suites consist of bedrooms, sitting rooms, bathrooms, and servant's rooms, and have their own private deck promenade isolated from the rest of the ship and not overlooked by any other passengers." "The Titanic also possesses another new feature in its Louis XVI. restaurant. Her sister ship, the Olympic, also has this feature but on a smaller scale. It proved so popular, however, that the White Star Company decided to have the one on the Titanic greatly enlarged."

But the great Boston fire of 1872 proved an impressive object lesson. Guarded by troops, the Union safe deposit vaults were a center of excitement. Frantic box holders, alarmed by the annihilation of property on every side, had to be forcibly restrained from taking possession of their valuables. After the fire was over, it was found that properly constructed vaults preserved their contents unharmed, while safes of the very best make could offer no effectual resistance to the fire.

The movement for the adoption of standard fire hose couplings dates from the great Boston fire of 1872, which showed the impossibility of the fire departments of adjacent towns acting in unison when provided with the diverse sizes of hose fittings then prevailing.

OBSERVATIONS ON THE! GREAT BOSTON FIRE OF 1872 A bundle of newspapers lie before me, dated November 11, 1872, the da> after the great Boston fire; it was Saturday night, the 9th, when it broke out; it raged all of that night and I Sunday forenoon, during the latter) day news of it reached me a hundred miles away; Monday I went there,! and found soldiers on guard all about 1 the burnt district; 1 was supplied with I a newspaper pass and began my in-1 vestigations, and familiar as I had been with that city since childhood,' although having never had a home there, 1 had to stop many times to decide which of two outlines of streets was the proper one; only those who have seen a greaf city after be ing devastated by fire can imagine the great change which it makes. After receiving my pass from the police department I went to Washington street and stood at the head of Milk street; an my left hand was the Old South Church of historic fame; across that street one building and beyond that only a vista of ruins, actually smoking ruins, and from where 1 stood I could look out on to the har bor; here and there stood a stone pil lar or two with the crossbeam, re minding me of the familiar pictures of ancient ruins. I had often wondered how big cities could be so completely destroyed as multitudes of great ones have been; but with that first sight of the Boston ruuis I understood it; twentyfour hourse had made the busy business part a ruin; I sought out the street where a nephew had been a clerk in a hardware store; I located the point where the great store had stood; nothing remained except melt ed piles of iron and steel goods; from among them I took what had been a package of carpet tacks, melted into one mass; that night my nephew told me how on Sunday when he got to the store the fire was several blocks away, and he and his associates began removing the stock, the fire creeping nearer all the while, till suddenly the flames burst into the back end of the store, it seeming as though the fire swept through the room as fast as they could run out of it."Why the flames should have march ed steadily to the windward against all common reason but repeats what great conflagrations have jefore ex hibited as a curiosity of fire. At the Journal office when the fire broke out there was no sense of insecurity (it was a third of a mile distant), and even after Summer street was a mass of flames (an eighth of a mile away). Why should there be? The wind blew steadily in the direction to carry the fire away from us. Still, with a malig nant relentlessness the fire reached towards us against the wind. It is said that the rarifying of the air aid ed by the wind creates a vacuum that is filled again by the flames and creeps along licking up everything in its way, and making its march really a backward one."

Subjoined we print a letter from a prominent physician in the East con cerning the alleged existence of the plague in San Francisco. We know that no San Francisco daily would print this letter, and we very much doubt whether any other San Francisco paper would print it. But the Argonaut would be unworthy of the trust in which its read ers hold it which trust is evidenced by the language of this letter were we to refuse to print an honest expression of opinion because we did not agree wiih the writer. Dr. Brumer says: 247 State St., Albany N. T., November 10, 190L Editors Argonaut As a constant reader and admirer of the Argonaut, and as a physician, I take the liberty j of writing to you. In your issue of October 2S, 1901, you write an editorial on the plague situa tion, in which you, Indirectly it is true, support the statement of the commis- ; sion of the State Board of Health "that there was not then and never had been a case of plague in San Fran cisco." Sur-lv vou have failed to inform ' yourself on the other side of this Ques- . tion. Let me refer you to articles on ' j the plague by Drs. Baker, Flexner and Novy in the American Journal of the I Medical Sciences for October, 1901. I These articles were partly based on a : study of plague cases made in San ' Franciseo. Let me further refer you ; to an article headed "San Francisco ; Plague Report," In the Journal of the American Medical Association of Octo- ; ber f. 1901. In this report, two certain j cases of plague and one probable case are reported. These cases are publish ' ed since the report of your commission. but some time before your editorial. , That the city authorities were cogni zant of them is shown by the fact that the city bacteriologist. Dr. Kellogg, is ' reported to have examined one ease. 1 1 would further call your attention to : the fact that the report of the commis sion, which you support, though it may ! satisfy the lay mind, is sadly larking in some points from a medical stand point. It states that plague was not the cause of death, but does not state what did cause death, nor who con ducted the examinations. J I WOOld not take the trouble to write to yon if I did not feel that you fall to appreciate the gravity of the stand . which you take. Your steady insistence ; that there is no danger of an epidemic I leads me to believe that you have been misinformed as to certain of the medi i eal aspects of the plague. I would I merely all your attention to the rec ognised fact that many epidemics of plague besin by the appearance of spo radic cases of a relatively mild type, Sltcn cases often lasting over months or even years, and being followed by explosive and widespread outbreaks ol tin disease It is through this stage ' of sporadic cases that San Francisro ! is now going, and the possibility of an extensive outbreak can not be denied, j Would it not be better candidly to ac knowledge the presence of the disease and counsel vigorous action for its ex termination, rather than to lull ine citizens into a sense of false security by editorials such as the one I have referred to?

Honolulu is quarantining against San Francisco on account of the epidemic of bubonic plague now in the Coast city, and hereafter every vessel leaving San Francisco for Hawaii ports will be required to be fumigated before departure and receive the certificate of the health authorities at San Francisco that the ship and crew have undergone quarantine. Though Honolulu has been a clean port for months, the California health authorities have required that vessels leaving here for San Francisco be fumigated, and otherwise handled here prior to departure, the Honolulu quarantine service certifying to such handling. Now Honolulu quarantines against San Francisco, and the ports are quarantined against each other. Dr. Carl Ramus, assistant surgeon, United States Marine Hospital service, for this port, in charge in the absence of Dr. Cofer, yesterday received from Washington cabled instructions to at once apply the quarantine to all vessels from San Francisco on account of an epidemic of bubonic plague there. San Francisco has been doing everything possible to keep quiet the fact of plague existing there and has been most demanding in requiring that vessels undergo quarantine and be fumigated here before leaving for that city or be held up there for several days under the yellow flag. San Francisco seemed to fear that plague might be introduced there from this port, whereas there are good reasons to believe, now, that the few cases of plague which have occurred on this island in past months may have been brought here from San Francisco. Plague conditions are serious in San Francisco. John Kelly, the Sierra's coal passer who had the disease, came from E street, near the Ferry building, San Francisco, in the district from which numerous cases of plague were taken. The orders from Washington, sent to San Francisco and to this port, ordering boats leaving the Golden Gate to leave clean for Hawaii and ordering Honolulu to see that they get here clean, in order to protect Honolulu from the San Francisco plague, double the burden on all vessels plying between the two ports.

UNTENABLE THEORY. That plague was introduced into San Francisco from Honolulu is not a tenable theory; yet there will be plenty of people up there ready to jump at such a conclusion. The passengers who have gone up to the Coast have all been cabin passengers, people who have not been exposed to infection by living in crowded tenement houses or in the crowded portions of the city. They have always been under the surveillance of Dr. Carmichael for fifteen days before leaving. Their baggage has been most carefully fumigated here before going on board, and has again been fumigated upon its arrival in San Francisco. The plague center in San Francisco is, as it was here, Chinatown. Now the Hawaiian passengers who have gone from here to San Francisco certainly did not take up their abode in Chinatown. They kept as far away from it as possible. With a Chinatown of our own, which we have been only too happy to have got rid of, the Chinatown of San Francisco could have no attraction for our people. If, therefore, it had been possible for any passenger to have taken the infection from here, the plague cases would not have broken out in San Francisco's Chinatown, but in some other part of the city. It has not done so, and the case is clearly in our favor. No infection was carried or could have been carried by passengers and their baggage. Next, it may be claimed that goods carried it up. Now, as a fact, no goods have been shipped from Honolulu. Whatever sugar has gone out of this harbor has been transferred to vessels in the stream from clean steamers which have carried the freight from plantations where there has not been a trace of plague. Indeed, it is wonderful that we have been able to isolate our people so thoroughly and confine the plague to so small an area. Moreover, the cargoes that have gone from here have not gone into Chinese hands. Not a pound of freight has gone from Honolulu to San Francisco's Chinatown. Had our products been infected, the disease would have appeared in some other part of San Francisco. It did not so appear. It was not and could not be infected because it came from places which were uninfected. The wolf charged the lamb who was below him for troubling the stream, and to charge that Honolulu carried infection to San Francisco savors very much of the same style of argument. We have never satisfactorily decided how plague came to us. The probability is that it came in certain China food. Some of this probably became too offensive even for the Celestial stomach and was thrown into backyards to rot and fester after the approved Celestial fashion. The rats banquetted upon the garbage, assimilated the microbes, and started the ball rolling. From the rats, as is usual, the plague spread to the human family. That is one theory. If this theory be correct, the same process would certainly bring about the plague in San Francisco. The San Francisco Chinese are far more addicted to Chinese food than the Hawaiian Chinese. The place reeks with rotting delicacies, as any one's nose will tell him if he has ever passed through the Chinese quarter of that city. Any quantity of Chinese comestibles are imported into San Francisco direct from Hongkong and other Chinese ports. The Hawaiian Islands have nothing to do with these imports, and it is in them that the danger of plague to San Francisco lies. Another theory about plague is that the germs breed in filth. If that is so, the filth of Chinatown is quite abundant enough to breed the microbes itself. San Francisco will have to seek the cause of its outbreak within its own portals, and not look to Hawaii as a pest-bearing center.

WASHINGTON PASSES ON THE SAN FRANCISCO PLAGUE As a result of a final decision that its Chinatown is infected with plague, San Francisco is renovating and disinfecting Chinatown, under the supervision of an officer of the United States Marine Hospital service. The Government health authorities at Washington finally took the matter up, and there appears to be no further doubt that plague has existed for some time, in the Chinese quarters of San Francisco. Information on the subject is so successfully kept from the public that only the scientific journals tell the story. The Plague Scare in San Francisco The Post of March 21st, the day the Mariposa left, has the following on the San Francisco plague affair: The Health Department is about to make its second assault upon the sanitary and other conditions of Chinatown, and with the rising sun tomorrow nearly 200 stalwart employees of the department will enter upon the task of uprooting evil spots, turning untidy stalls into the streets, destroying undesirable or dangerous structures and fixtures, burning tainted provisions, and flushing out hidden retreats and many nooks which have not been in speaking terms with pure water for many a day. A hundred deputies are being instructed in the work of reclamation today, and tomorrow morning they will swoop down upon the offending quarter and apply the hose and broom with vigor. Fifty police officers especially detailed for the work are to aid and many others are to take part who have hitherto been engaged elsewhere by the health officers. An order was issued early this morning, instructing the garbage collectors to leave their loads in Chinatown today, to be burned there. This is in order to prevent the stuff even being carried through the streets of the city. On a vacant lot near Dupont and Clay streets, a force of men was at work all day today burning up the garbage and debris as it was brought to them. A death at 723 Sacramento Street, another at 905 Dupont Street, and a third in Oneida Place are the fatalities that stimulated the Health Board to immediate action, and from these it is feared a number of other deaths will soon follow. While the authorities do not claim that the bubonic plague has lifted its head or broken out under cover, they do claim that the filth and poor sanitary conditions of the district have caused an epidemic among the Chinese which may any day develop into the plague and become widespread. In the three cases mentioned, the cause of death has not been definitely known, and the authorities intimate that it may be the plague in a mild form. It is this state of affairs that has led to the campaign against uncleanness and stagnation in the houses and streets of the Oriental district. Glands from the three subjects which have now puzzled the authorities are under examination, but no positive verdict has been rendered by Dr. Kinyoun, the Federal bacteriologist, and Dr. Kellogg in the municipal service. The authorities will neither assert nor deny that the cases are those of bubonic plague.
